origin_history: Part of mixed Herb Planter seeded on Nov 12, 2025.
Planted in black planter 23.5" \xd7 7.85" \xd7 6" right back.
Shares planter with Thai Basil, Cilantro, Oregano, and Parsley.
whats_been_logged: The focus has been on tracking germination timing, seedling emergence patterns, and early moisture distribution as thyme progressed from seed to a dense carpet of tiny seedlings. Probe readings documented pH correction efforts using lime, moisture stability across the zone, and continued expansion of the seedling mat.
current_state: Thyme plants show healthy vegetative growth with multiple true leaves, upright stems, and expanding lateral spread across the zone. Foliage is evenly green with no visible spotting, wilting, or burn. The crown areas appear clean and stable, and the plants are well anchored despite recent wet soil conditions.

timeline.what_i_should_see: Mature Herb Mat / Regular Harvest Cycle

journal.conditions: Sunny with a high of 82\xb0F dropping to 66\xb0F overnight.
journal.observations: Thyme shows upright, firm stems with healthy green foliage and visible new growth tips. Soil structure appears loose and evenly aerated, with moisture in an ideal range following several days of drying and flushing. No signs of burn, collapse, or stress are visible, and nutrient levels have stabilized at low, appropriate levels for thyme.
journal.actions: Do not water or fertilize today. Maintain current conditions and allow the soil to continue a gentle dry-down cycle.
journal.next_steps: Recheck probe readings at the next session. Consider watering only if moisture drops below approximately 35 and foliage shows early signs of thirst.

photos.caption: Thyme showing upright growth, healthy foliage, and evenly aerated soil under stable moisture conditions.

journal.conditions: Patchy fog before 8 AM, otherwise partly sunny with a high near 84\xb0F dropping to around 61\xb0F overnight.
journal.observations: Thyme shows upright, firm stems with stable green foliage and visible new growth tips. Soil moisture has declined out of the saturation range following several wet days, and the surface appears moist but no longer waterlogged. Nutrient, EC, and salt levels continue trending downward, consistent with natural flushing and improving root-zone oxygen.
journal.actions: Do not water or fertilize today. Allow continued natural dry-down through tonight and tomorrow.
journal.next_steps: Recheck probe readings tomorrow late morning or early afternoon. Consider light watering only if moisture drops below approximately 35.

photos.caption: Overhead view of thyme showing upright growth and stable foliage as soil moisture begins to normalize.
Close-up of thyme stems and leaves showing healthy color and no signs of burn or collapse after drying period.

journal.conditions: Partly sunny with a high of 83\xb0F dropping to 67\xb0F overnight.
journal.observations: Thyme remains upright and green with firm stems and no visible burn, collapse, or rot. Repeated rainfall this morning kept the root zone fully saturated, re-suspending nutrients from earlier fertilization and maintaining elevated EC, salt, and fertility readings. Growth appears compact and slightly slowed, consistent with prolonged wet conditions rather than stress or toxicity.
journal.actions: Do not water, fertilize, or disturb the soil today. Allow sun, airflow, and evaporation to gradually reduce moisture levels.
journal.next_steps: Recheck probe readings after a clear drying window. Expect EC and salt to decline once moisture drops below saturated levels. Monitor for stem softening or rapid leaf yellowing if wet conditions persist.

photos.caption: Overhead view of thyme showing compact, upright growth and stable green foliage after morning rainfall.
Close-up of thyme stems and leaves showing no burn, rot, or collapse despite saturated soil conditions.

journal.conditions: Mostly sunny with a high near 80\xb0F dropping to around 65\xb0F overnight.
journal.observations: Thyme remains upright and green with firm stems and no visible burn, rot, or collapse. Strong winds dried and crusted the soil surface, making probe insertion difficult, while deeper soil layers remained saturated. After taking readings, the soil surface was gently fluffed to restore aeration and break surface crusting. Elevated but declining EC, salt, and fertility reflect residual nutrients from earlier fertilization rather than active stress.
journal.actions: Do not water or fertilize today. Leave the soil undisturbed after fluffing and allow natural drying and rainfall to rebalance moisture and nutrients.
journal.next_steps: Recheck probe readings in 24\u201348 hours and expect moisture, EC, and salt to continue declining. Lightly fluff again only if surface crusting reforms after rain or wind.

photos.caption: Thyme showing upright stems and healthy green foliage after soil surface was fluffed to relieve wind-related crusting.

journal.conditions: A 20 percent chance of showers and thunderstorms, partly sunny with a high of 81\xb0F dropping to 63\xb0F overnight.
journal.observations: Thyme remains upright and green with no visible burn, collapse, or rot despite very wet soil conditions. The root zone is fully saturated following recent rainfall and fertilization, and additional Miracle-Gro Potting Mix was added to fill probe holes and even out the soil surface. Elevated EC, salt, and fertility readings reflect lingering nutrients in solution rather than plant stress.
journal.actions: Do not water or fertilize today. Allow wind and sun to dry the soil naturally and avoid pressing or compacting the newly added potting mix.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture and EC after 24\u201348 hours of drying. Expect nutrient and salt levels to decline as oxygen returns to the root zone. Continue monitoring for yellowing or softening at the stem base.

photos.caption: Thyme showing upright stems and healthy green foliage with newly leveled soil after filling probe holes.

journal.conditions: Showers likely with a high of 81\xb0F dropping to 63\xb0F overnight.
journal.observations: Thyme shows stable, healthy growth with upright stems and green leaves, with no visible burn, spotting, or collapse. The soil is visibly moist from rain, and the entire herb box was fertilized with 4 cups of diluted Purived 4-5-5, which aligns with today\u2019s elevated EC, salt, and fertility readings.
journal.actions: Do not water today or tomorrow unless the soil dries unexpectedly. Do not fertilize again for 14\u201321 days. Allow the planter to dry down naturally and avoid disturbing the soil surface while nutrient and salt levels redistribute.
journal.next_steps: Recheck probe readings after 48\u201372 hours of drying and expect EC/salt/fertility to trend down as moisture normalizes. Watch thyme for leaf paling, curling, or slowed growth; if readings remain elevated after a dry-down, plan a controlled dilution watering later.

photos.caption: Overhead view showing thyme with healthy green leaves and upright stems in moist soil conditions.

journal.conditions: Mostly sunny with a high of 79\xb0F dropping to 62\xb0F overnight.
journal.observations: Thyme seedlings form a healthy green carpet with strong stems and evenly hydrated soil. No signs of wilting, discoloration, or pests. The seedlings are gradually expanding as they develop true leaves.
journal.actions: No watering needed today; moisture is ideal. Optionally remove large bark pieces to allow better light access to smaller seedlings.
journal.next_steps: Monitor moisture tomorrow and watch for continued leaf development. Ensure surface doesn\u2019t dry out too much over the next few days.

photos.caption: Wider view of thyme seedlings on 12/12, showing healthy growth and expanding true leaves.
Close-up of thyme seedlings, showing vibrant green color and healthy leaf formation on 12/12.

journal.conditions: Mostly Sunny with a high of 77\xb0F dropping to 52\xb0F overnight.
journal.observations: Thyme seedlings show their strongest growth to date, with vibrant color and clearly expanding true leaves. The main cluster is thickening and stems are upright and sturdy. Satellite seedlings remain healthy and are gradually increasing in size. Soil is evenly hydrated from recent moisture, and no signs of wilting, spotting, or pest impact are present.
journal.actions: Do not water today; moisture is excellent. Avoid disturbing the soil surface. No fertilizer or amendments are needed at this stage. Optionally remove any very large bark pieces shading small seedlings.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture tomorrow midday as the surface begins drying. Monitor for continued mat thickening and the next tier of true leaves as the seedlings transition toward early mat development.

photos.caption: Morning thyme photo on 12/10 showing vigorous growth and expanding true leaves.
Wider view of the thyme zone on 12/10 showing healthy density and balanced hydration.
Close-up of individual thyme seedlings showing bright color and strong leaf formation.

journal.conditions: Slight Chance T-storms then Showers Likely with a high of 83\xb0F dropping to 63\xb0F overnight.
journal.observations: Thyme seedlings appear bright, even, and vigorous with well-formed true leaves. The cluster is thickening and color is uniform across the zone. Soil structure looks improved after filling the probe hole and adding fresh potting mix, creating more even moisture retention. No wilting, fungal issues, or discoloration are present.
journal.actions: Do not water today. Allow the soil to continue settling after rainfall and soil adjustments. Avoid fertilizer or lime. Remove only large bark pieces that shade seedlings without disturbing the cluster.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture and pH tomorrow once rainfall distribution stabilizes. Expect continued mat thickening and steady true-leaf development over the next several days.
follow_up: [4:38 PM] Sprayed Captain Jack\u2019s DeadBug lightly across the entire window box at soil level to eliminate or expose any cutworms that may have dropped into the soil and to prevent potential nighttime stem damage to cilantro and the other herbs.

photos.caption: Morning probe reading on 12/09 showing balanced moisture and improved pH.
Thyme seedlings on 12/09 showing dense growth and expanding true leaves.
Close-up of thyme cluster showing healthy coloration and strong early development.

journal.conditions: Slight Chance T-storms then Showers Likely with a high of 83\xb0F dropping to 63\xb0F overnight.
journal.observations: Thyme seedlings appear healthy and upright with increasingly defined true leaves. Color remains bright with only minor cotyledon yellowing typical of early-stage transitions. Soil is well rehydrated from the morning storms, and seedlings show no signs of wilting or stress. EC and salt are elevated due to rapid wetting of previously dry soil but pose no visible concern.
journal.actions: Do not water today. Allow the soil to continue settling after rainfall. Avoid fertilizer or lime adjustments. Lightly crumble only the loosest surface bark pieces without disturbing seedlings.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture and pH tomorrow once soil redistribution stabilizes. Expect EC and salt values to normalize within 24\u201348 hours. Continue monitoring for mat thickening and expansion of true leaves.

photos.caption: Digital probe reading on 12/08 showing elevated EC and salt after soil rehydration.
Thyme seedlings showing healthy green growth and expanding true leaves on 12/08.

journal.conditions: Sunny with a high of 86\xb0F dropping to 66\xb0F overnight.
journal.observations: Thyme seedlings appear healthy and upright with early true leaves forming. Color remains bright green with no signs of wilting or stress. The soil surface is extremely dry, preventing reliable moisture readings, though the seedlings themselves are tolerating conditions well. No damping-off or discoloration observed.
journal.actions: Gently moisten the thyme zone with no more than 1/2 cup of water to restore surface hydration and improve probe contact. Avoid deep watering today. Loosen only the driest surface crust without disturbing seedlings.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture after tomorrow\u2019s expected rainfall to confirm even hydration. Continue monitoring for mat thickening and early true leaf expansion. Avoid additional watering unless the surface becomes powder-dry.

photos.caption: Digital probe screenshot showing low moisture due to very dry soil surface on 12/07.
Thyme seedlings developing early true leaves with healthy green coloration on 12/07.

journal.conditions: Mostly cloudy with a high of 84\xb0F dropping to 67\xb0F overnight; wind gusts up to 19 mph.
journal.observations: Thyme seedlings show vigorous growth with clearly emerging true leaves and expanded green coverage. Soil is highly saturated following recent moisture retention, and wind exposure is helping dry the surface without stressing the plants.
journal.actions: Do not water today. Rotate probe insertion points and lightly loosen the top soil layer only if crusting develops.
journal.next_steps: Monitor soil drying over the next 24 hours and begin watching for thinning timing as true leaves continue developing.
journal.q_and_a_summary: User shared available garden products for reference and noted soil leveling and probe management improvements.

photos.caption: Digital probe reading showing high soil moisture and stable pH on 12/02.
Thyme seedlings with emerging true leaves and healthy green growth under morning sun.

journal.conditions: Cloudy with a high of 72\xb0F dropping to 57\xb0F overnight; clear conditions expected around 6 PM.
journal.observations: Thyme seedlings remain healthy with bright green cotyledons and gradual expansion across the leveled soil surface. A resolved probe depression has allowed more even distribution of new sprouts.
journal.actions: Do not water today. Continue filling the probe hole after each use and rotate probe locations to prevent new compaction.
journal.next_steps: Monitor soil surface later in the day; lightly fluff the top layer only if crusting appears.
journal.q_and_a_summary: User reported continued soil leveling and noted normal seedling expansion following improved soil structure.

photos.caption: Digital probe reading showing stable moisture and a temporary pH error on 11/28.
Thyme seedlings in morning light showing healthy cotyledons and improved soil leveling.

journal.conditions: Cloudy with a high of 81\xb0F dropping to 65\xb0F overnight; rain expected around 6 PM.
journal.observations: Thyme seedlings remain healthy with bright green cotyledons and a stable, dense cluster toward the upper section. Soil leveling efforts have smoothed the probe depression and improved distribution without burying seedlings.
journal.actions: Do not water ahead of rainfall. Continue lightly filling the probe hole after each use to prevent sinking and maintain an even surface.
journal.next_steps: After tonight's rain, check for soil displacement and confirm that the surface remains level for even seedling growth.
journal.q_and_a_summary: User noted that probe width caused repeated depressions and they began filling the hole and leveling soil beneath the thyme.

photos.caption: Digital probe reading at midday showing stable moisture and moderate pH on 11/27.
Thyme seedling cluster showing even green cotyledons and improved soil leveling beneath the plants.

journal.conditions: Mostly cloudy with a high of 84\xb0F dropping to 67\xb0F overnight; thunderstorms expected around 4 PM.
journal.observations: Thyme seedlings remain healthy with bright green cotyledons and steady spread toward the upper planting area. A noticeable soil depression has formed from repeated probe placement, causing seedlings to cluster at the top.
journal.actions: Add a thin layer of loose potting mix to level the probe pocket before the storm. Do not water ahead of rainfall.
journal.next_steps: After the storm, inspect for soil displacement and ensure the surface remains level for even seedling distribution.
journal.q_and_a_summary: User asked whether the probe-made soil depression should be filled due to seedling clustering; confirmed that it should be topped up with loose mix.

photos.caption: Digital probe reading at midday showing rising pH and moderate soil moisture on 11/26.
Thyme seedlings clustered toward the upper section due to a soil depression from repeated probe insertion.
Close-up of the probe pocket showing uneven soil level and seedling distribution.
Wider view of thyme zone showing clustering and the need for gentle soil leveling.

journal.conditions: Sunny all day with a high of 84\xb0F dropping to 65\xb0F overnight.
journal.observations: Thyme seedlings continued to appear healthy with appropriate moisture following afternoon watering. No signs of stress were observed despite warm soil temperatures.
journal.actions: No additional watering needed after the 2:33 PM irrigation. Allow surface to dry slightly before the next irrigation.
journal.next_steps: Monitor moisture patterns and ensure soil does not become overly dry in the upper layers.
journal.q_and_a_summary: User noted that watering occurred at 2:33 PM as morning watering was missed.

journal.conditions: Partly cloudy with a high of 81\xb0F dropping to 61\xb0F overnight.
journal.observations: Thyme seedlings appear healthy with bright green cotyledons and slightly expanded coverage. Soil has rehydrated well after the morning's light watering, and no stress indicators are present.
journal.actions: No immediate action needed. Allow soil to dry slightly at the surface before the next watering.
journal.next_steps: Continue monitoring surface dryness and seedling density as the carpet forms. Watch for first true leaves over the coming days.
journal.q_and_a_summary: User noted the soil was extremely dry and crumbly this morning and lightly watered before taking readings.

photos.caption: Midday digital probe reading for thyme showing rehydrated soil and rising pH on 11/24.
Thyme seedling cluster showing healthy green cotyledons and moist soil after a light watering on 11/24.

journal.conditions: Sunny with a high of 84\xb0F dropping to 63\xb0F overnight.
journal.observations: Thyme seedlings continue expanding evenly across the thyme zone with healthy bright green cotyledons. No stress indicators present despite warm soil temperatures. Surface soil shows moderate dryness but is not crusted, and moisture at depth remains stable.
journal.actions: Do not water now. Recheck surface dryness around sunset and provide a gentle shallow watering only if the top layer becomes excessively dry.
journal.next_steps: Monitor for continued expansion of the seedling carpet and watch for the arrival of the first true leaves over the next 1-2 weeks.

photos.caption: Thyme seedlings expanding across the zone in bright sun on 11/23.

journal.conditions: Mostly cloudy with a high of 84\xb0F dropping to 67\xb0F overnight.
journal.observations: Thyme seedlings continue forming a healthy, bright green carpet with slightly increased density compared to the previous day. Soil surface appears moderately dry but seedlings show no stress symptoms. pH remains acidic but stable within the expected lime-buffering range.
journal.actions: Check surface dryness mid-afternoon. Provide a gentle, shallow watering only if the top layer becomes powder-dry or crusted. No fertilizer or pH adjustments today.
journal.next_steps: Monitor moisture trends to prevent excessive drying during seedling establishment. Watch for the first true leaves over the next 1-2 weeks as the carpet continues to thicken.

photos.caption: Thyme seedling cluster expanding slightly under mostly cloudy late-morning conditions on 11/22.

journal.conditions: Sunny with a high of 84\xb0F dropping to 60\xb0F overnight.
journal.observations: Thyme seedlings are expanding into a denser carpet and appear healthy under bright afternoon sun. Soil moisture is strong at depth despite a drying surface, and pH remains acidic but trending upward after lime application. No signs of wilting, bleaching, or damping off.
journal.actions: Do not water at peak heat; soil moisture at depth is sufficient. Optionally mist lightly near sunset only if the surface becomes extremely dry and crusted.
journal.next_steps: Monitor pH over the next 48 hours as lime continues to buffer acidity. Watch for continued thickening of the seedling carpet and ensure surface dryness does not reach a powdery state.

photos.caption: Bright and expanding cluster of thyme seedlings in full afternoon sun on 11/21.

journal.conditions: Mostly sunny with a high of 83\xb0F dropping to 64\xb0F overnight.
journal.observations: Thyme seedlings form a dense, bright green carpet and appear healthy despite the hot afternoon conditions. Moisture reading is low, showing that the surface is drying out compared to previous days.
journal.actions: Hold off on immediate watering at peak heat but plan to give a gentle, even watering over the thyme zone later if seedlings begin to wilt or the top layer becomes very dry.
journal.next_steps: Over the next 24 hours, monitor for signs of wilting or yellowing in the dense thyme mat. Plan for future thinning once seedlings are larger and the stand stabilizes.

photos.caption: Dense carpet of thyme seedlings in full sun on 11/20 with drying surface soil.

journal.conditions: Cool morning around 69.1\xb0F in full sun with clear weather.
journal.observations: Dense healthy thyme germination with bright green clustered seedlings.
journal.actions: Do not water. Allow slight drying.
journal.next_steps: Monitor density for thinning later.
follow_up: [3:07 PM] Lime added across herb box; soil very dry two knuckles down\u2014light surface watering recommended to re-moisten the upper layer without washing lime deeper.

photos.caption: Dense thyme sprout cluster on 11/19.
Herb box after lime application on the afternoon of 11/19.

journal.conditions: Cool morning around 64.6\xb0F in full sun with partly cloudy weather, high 82\xb0F, low 65\xb0F.
journal.observations: First tiny thyme sprouts beginning to emerge across the section. Seedlings are very small but bright and evenly distributed.
journal.actions: Do not water today. Allow the surface to remain slightly on the dry side to prevent damping off.
journal.next_steps: Monitor thyme sprouts closely and watch for expansion of the seedling carpet.

photos.caption: First tiny thyme sprouts visible in the thyme zone on 11/18.

journal.conditions: Cool morning around 60.6\xb0F in full sun with mostly sunny weather, high 81\xb0F, low 61\xb0F.
journal.observations: First thyme sprouts are visible as tiny green specks across the thyme zone. Soil moisture is good; pH is still on the acidic side but seedlings look healthy.
journal.actions: Avoid additional watering today and do not disturb emerging thyme seedlings.
journal.next_steps: Monitor thyme sprout expansion over the next 2-3 days. Recheck moisture if the surface begins to dry.

photos.caption: Close-up of first thyme sprouts appearing on 11/17.

journal.conditions: Cool morning around 67\xb0F in morning shade then sun with clear weather.
journal.observations: Soil is still on the dry side but improving compared to the previous day. No sprouts visible in this section yet.
journal.actions: Provide a gentle watering to keep the top layer evenly moist. No fertilizer.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture the next morning and continue watching for first signs of germination.

photos.caption: Herb planter surface on 11/13 showing moistening soil and no sprouts yet.

journal.conditions: Cool morning around 65\xb0F in full sun with clear weather.
journal.observations: Initial reading shows very dry soil and alkaline pH across the planter. No seedlings present; seeds are likely just beginning water uptake after sowing.
journal.actions: Thoroughly soak the soil to correct dryness, taking care not to displace seeds. No fertilizer at this stage.
journal.next_steps: Expect slow pH change over the coming days. Recheck moisture and pH with follow-up readings.

photos.caption: First-day view of the herb planter on 11/12 with dry soil before rehydration.
